news1.title: Historic Surrender of Pakistan Army in Dhaka
news1.summary: On December 16, 1971, the Pakistan Army officially surrendered to the joint forces of Bangladesh and India, marking the end of the Liberation War and the birth of independent Bangladesh.
news1.content: The instrument of surrender was signed by Lieutenant General A. A. K. Niazi, commander of the Pakistani forces in East Pakistan, and Lieutenant General Jagjit Singh Aurora, GOC-in-C of the Indian and Bangladesh forces, at the Ramna Race Course in Dhaka. This historic event led to the unconditional surrender of approximately 93,000 Pakistani troops, the largest surrender since World War II. The joyous occasion was met with widespread celebrations across Bangladesh, symbolizing the culmination of nine months of valiant struggle and immense sacrifice.

news2.title: The Role of Mukti Bahini in Bangladesh's Independence
news2.summary: The Mukti Bahini, or Freedom Fighters, played a pivotal role in the Bangladesh Liberation War, employing guerrilla tactics and immense bravery against the Pakistani military.
news2.content: Comprised of Bengali military, paramilitary, and civilians, the Mukti Bahini emerged as a formidable force following the crackdown by the Pakistani army on March 25, 1971. Their guerrilla warfare disrupted Pakistani supply lines, ambushed convoys, and liberated various areas, significantly contributing to the morale of the Bengali populace and weakening the Pakistani occupation forces. Their unwavering commitment and sacrifice were instrumental in achieving the long-sought independence.

news3.title: March 7 Speech: A Call for Independence
news3.summary: Sheikh Mujibur Rahman's historic speech on March 7, 1971, at the Ramna Race Course in Dhaka, effectively declared Bangladesh's independence and galvanized the nation.
news3.content: In front of a massive gathering, Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman delivered a powerful and inspiring speech that is considered a de facto declaration of Bangladesh's independence. He famously declared, "The struggle this time is for our emancipation! The struggle this time is for our independence!" The speech outlined the grievances against West Pakistan, called for a non-cooperation movement, and prepared the Bengali people for the impending war. It remains a foundational document in the history of Bangladesh.

news4.title: The Genocide of 1971: A Dark Chapter
news4.summary: The 1971 Bangladesh Genocide, initiated by the Pakistani military's Operation Searchlight, resulted in the systematic killing of millions of Bengalis and widespread atrocities.
news4.content: Beginning on March 25, 1971, with Operation Searchlight, the Pakistani army launched a brutal campaign of genocide against the Bengali population, targeting intellectuals, students, Hindus, and political activists. Estimates suggest that between 500,000 and 3,000,000 Bengalis were killed, and millions more were displaced and sought refuge in India. The atrocities included mass murders, rape, and forced displacement, leaving an indelible scar on the nation's history and highlighting the immense human cost of the Liberation War.

news5.title: International Support for Bangladesh's Liberation War
news5.summary: The Bangladesh Liberation War garnered significant international support, particularly from India, which played a crucial role in providing military and humanitarian aid.
news5.content: Beyond India's direct military intervention, various countries and international organizations voiced support for Bangladesh's independence. India provided sanctuary to millions of refugees, trained and equipped the Mukti Bahini, and eventually intervened militarily. Other nations, through diplomatic pressure and humanitarian assistance, also contributed to the global recognition of the atrocities committed by Pakistan and the legitimacy of Bangladesh's struggle for self-determination. This international solidarity was vital in securing Bangladesh's swift victory.

event1.title: National Assembly Elections
event1.description: The Awami League, led by Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, wins a landslide victory in the National Assembly elections.

event2.title: Leaders Vow to Implement Programs
event2.description: Sheikh Mujib and other leaders meet at Ramna Race Course, vowing to implement the six-point program and an 11-point charter.

event3.title: Historic Speech at Race Course Ground
event3.description: Sheikh Mujib delivers a historic speech at Race Course Ground (now Suhrawardy Udyan), calling for civil disobedience and hinting at independence.

event4.title: Operation Searchlight Initiated
event4.description: The Pakistan Army initiates Operation Searchlight, a violent crackdown in Dhaka and other regions.

event5.title: Declaration of Independence
event5.description: Sheikh Mujib declares Bangladesh's independence before his arrest by Pakistani forces.

event6.title: Provisional Government Formed
event6.description: A provisional government-in-exile is formed, with Sheikh Mujib as President and Tajuddin Ahmad as Prime Minister.

event7.title: Operation Jackpot Executed
event7.description: Operation Jackpot is executed by Mukti Bahini naval commandos, targeting Pakistani naval ships.

event8.title: India Joins the War
event8.description: India officially joins the war after pre-emptive attacks by Pakistan on western borders.

event9.title: Victory Day - Liberation of Bangladesh
event9.description: Pakistan surrenders, ending the nine-month war. An estimated 3 million people died in Bangladesh.

event10.title: Sheikh Mujib Returns to Dhaka
event10.description: Sheikh Mujib returns to Dhaka after being released from Pakistani custody.

event11.title: Sheikh Mujib Becomes Prime Minister
event11.description: Sheikh Mujib becomes the Prime Minister of Bangladesh.

event12.title: Constitution of Bangladesh Adopted
event12.description: The Constitution of Bangladesh is adopted.

exhibition1.title: Voices of Freedom: Personal Stories from 1971
exhibition1.description: Delve into the poignant and powerful personal narratives of individuals who lived through the tumultuous 1971 Bangladesh Liberation War. This exhibition presents a curated collection of diaries, letters, oral testimonies, and rare photographs, offering an intimate glimpse into the resilience, sacrifices, and unwavering spirit of ordinary people who became extraordinary heroes. Hear the echoes of their courage, their hopes, and their enduring fight for a sovereign nation.
exhibition1.curatorNote: This exhibition is a tribute to the human spirit during adversity. Through these deeply personal accounts, we aim to transcend historical facts and connect visitors with the emotional landscape of the Liberation War. Each voice, whether of a freedom fighter, a civilian, or a refugee, contributes to a rich tapestry of remembrance, ensuring that their experiences are never forgotten and continue to inspire future generations.

exhibition2.title: Weapons of Liberation: The Arsenal of Freedom
exhibition2.description: Step into the arsenal of the Mukti Bahini, where ingenuity met necessity in the fight for independence. This exhibition showcases the diverse array of weaponry, from antiquated rifles to improvised explosives, that played a crucial role in the 1971 Liberation War. Beyond the artifacts themselves, explore the stories of how these tools were acquired, adapted, and wielded by brave freedom fighters against a formidable foe. Understand the logistical challenges and the sheer determination that fueled their armed struggle.
exhibition2.curatorNote: This exhibition serves as a powerful reminder of the resourcefulness and unwavering resolve of the Mukti Bahini. Each weapon on display, regardless of its origin or sophistication, embodies a piece of their struggle and sacrifice. We aim to present not just the instruments of war, but the human stories behind them—the hands that held them, the courage they represented, and the ultimate victory they helped secure for Bangladesh.

exhibition3.title: Documents of Destiny: Official Records and Declarations
exhibition3.description: Journey through the pivotal official records, declarations, and diplomatic correspondences that meticulously charted the course of Bangladesh's independence. This exhibition uncovers the profound legal, political, and international dimensions of the 1971 Liberation War. From the historic Proclamation of Independence to key treaties and resolutions, these documents reveal the intricate diplomatic efforts and the unwavering commitment to self-determination that culminated in the birth of a new nation.
exhibition3.curatorNote: The documents presented here are more than mere historical artifacts; they are the bedrock of Bangladesh's sovereignty and identity. This exhibition illuminates the intellectual and strategic battles fought in the halls of power and international forums, complementing the armed struggle on the ground. By delving into these crucial papers, visitors will gain a deeper appreciation for the foundational principles and the monumental efforts that underpinned the creation of an independent Bangladesh.
